gpt-message.content: You are an expert in hardware design with a deep understanding of Verilog RTL codes. Now I want to train a large language model for code comment generation tasks specifically focused on Verilog RTL codes. And I want you to help me process the raw data, transforming it into suitable formats that can serve as inputs and outputs for the model.

Name of the module and its functionality is as follows: 
The provided Verilog code seems to be corrupted or contains non-readable characters. This prevents me from accurately determining the module name or its functionality based on the code and comments.

Please provide a clear, uncorrupted version of the Verilog code so that I can accurately process your request.

Input and output ports and their explanation is as follows: 
The code provided in the initial request appears to be corrupted or contains non-readable characters, which makes it non-interpretable as Verilog code or any readable text. Consequently, it is impossible for me to accurately discern the input and output ports of the module or provide explanations for each port based on the given data.

To progress with your request, please provide a clear, uncorrupted version of the Verilog RTL code. This will enable me to provide detailed and accurate answers regarding the input and output ports of the module, along with their respective explanations.

Internal signals and their explanation is as follows: 
As previously mentioned, the code you provided is corrupted or contains non-readable characters, which prevents me from interpreting it as valid Verilog RTL code. Without a clear and accurate depiction of the code, it's impossible to determine internal signals or provide explanations for them.

To assist you properly with information about internal signals used in a module and to give a simple explanation of each in relation to its role in the module, please ensure you provide an uncorrupted, readable version of the Verilog RTL code. This will enable me to deliver concise and exact information regarding the module's internal signal structure.
